12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, stream, dugout) ... FROM A. AVE. NO. 917, ABOVE NO. 385, NEAR ARBLED, ...

If so, how far was this water from your house? about 60 feet.

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank) by PAIL

For another water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading. Giving dates where possible.

The water in the 30' well was not reliable; and the supply was not brought into the district; and deep wells about 150 feet brought in a good supply of water.

Notice any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, river dates thereof possible.

Coal was available at the nearest town 30 miles away—if one had the price—$1.00 a ton. Coal wood was the main source of fuel until the advent of the railway in 1928. Coal could then be obtained at the Elevators (just only) seven mile haul.

Prior to good coal was around $12.00 a ton.

15. In the early days the food was wrapped in brown paper or beeswax paper for perishable goods like apples, etc.

16. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest years you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family who lived there at the time. Include any special occasions or holidays.

17. That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in postwar times? If so, give the menu. List those present and note their ages.

18. How did you respond to almost starvation level living conditions locally produced foods? Give details. No; we were always able to dig up a meal; even though it might consist of potatoes and bread and butter. And we usually had eggs.
16. What are your experiences which you recall in the teaching and organization of classes with the food you served? Have these been positive or negative?

In the early days the food was prepared by Mrs. Smith, who was a skilled cook.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest years at the school. Include the approximate number of students present each day.

Breakfast: 8:00 a.m. - Oatmeal porridge, toast, tea, milk.
Lunch: 12:00 p.m. - Sandwiches, fruit, milk.
Supper: 5:00 p.m. - Stew, bread, butter, milk.

18. Tell us about your first Christmas dinner in January 1908.

The menu included roast turkey, ham, potatoes, peas, onion soup, plum pudding, and mince pies.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on only locally produced foods? Give details.

No; we were always able to dig up a meal even though it might consist of potatoes and bread and butter, and we usually had eggs.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earlier days compared with today.

In the early days we had to make our own foods - bread, cakes, cookies, etc.; how these can be purchased as cheaply as one can make them; thus relieving the housewife of the arduous task of a lot of work. The menu of today is more varied; but to my mind not as nourishing.

21. When did you begin to rely on prepared foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home preserved foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

The change came almost imperceptibly; the advent of the railway brought us nearer to supplies at the local stores and canned foods became available; this was in 1929.

Canned goods were always available if one had the time to drive 30 miles to town and had the money to buy. We got along without them as long as possible.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences as a buyer of groceries and selecting foods in other ways during pioneer days in Eastern Carolina.

Includes items not mentioned above, quality, methods of preserving, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other things.

As the years went on we got more stock around us the fresh meat problem was solved. In 1915 the first beef ring was formed; but for some reason the beef rings were not a success. During the winter we canned a half a beef for summer use; and we never had to throw away a bad can. Took great care with the canning process; also canned whatever fish was left from winter and all the canned food stored well.

Our family of 6 boys, 3 girls, lived on a farm, raised many chickens, and saved up enough money to buy a cow and sell her at the end of the year.

We were all very healthy and worked hard.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homemade and home preserved foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

The change came almost imperceptibly; the advent of the railway brought us nearer to supplies at the local stores. Canned foods were always available if one had the time to drive 30 miles to town; and had the money to buy. We got along without them as long as possible.
